transcript: For all forecasting, basically commercial forecasting,
forecasting on sea, land, and so on.

And, you know, those are long hours so some of them fall out so that was the first thing i kind of to me it seemed comparing to some departments that i don't find that important let's put it way kind of weather concerns us all you know like so they are actually getting funding for too few people so they seem to be seriously underfunded it seems and then the second thing was he was really talking about uh this synergy now between uh they were mostly using simulations and now it's kind of getting more and more prediction like more more art type of stuff let's put it way uh and it's great you know like you can uh do more apparently if you use the boat so the catch is also i think that at some point politics also gets involved i was just before that reading this there were articles in science and nature about this ipcc report on uh climate change know the long-awaited one ten years nine years I don't know they do it with kind of these kind of patterns you remember Greta crying and things so apparently based on the report it seemed well the earth is warming up much faster than we anticipated. So there come reports in Science and Nature, even from the authors of the IPCC, that the predictions were seriously off. And I think the title of the article in Science and Nature was, Use of Too Hot Climate Models Undermines Trust in Science, or something like that. I was like, okay, where does this come from? So you know what somebody noticed? They were using, for that report, now again, if I remember correctly, 50-some different models, national models. And they were all predicting kind of increase in temperature in a similar range. But five were, I think, those were nasa noaa british math institute canadian equivalent and the department of energy those five are having a increase of five plus and some people actually apparently objected but you know it's trusted institutions you know like so didn't raise much or too many flags so they use something they call algorithm democracy to combine those scores so it ended up apparently higher than it should be so there is an interesting science article magazine science article and also nature uh so

description:
The most fitting category for this segment is **Cooking**.

Here's why:

*   **Visible Food Items:** The table is laden with food items like croissants, fruit, and what appears to be ingredients for a meal.
*   **Baking Racks:** Several baking racks are prominently displayed on the table, strongly suggesting preparation for baking or cooking.
*   **Kitchen Setting:** The scene is set in a kitchen with a refrigerator, countertops, and kitchen appliances visible in the background.
*   **People's Actions:** While not explicitly shown in the act of cooking, the overall context and the presence of cooking equipment imply that cooking is the primary activity.

transcript: They requested that we run something that's like BBS or LSE, or BBS and LSE actually, actually. Add see actually I'd ACM multimedia get together figure it out do it it has to be interactive you didn't say that but since I said it has to be like it should be like VBS LSE it probably is something with an attractive element to it they just had get a training data, maybe a closed workshop and a public open session. That is what I think is going to happen. So look for something that's not the obvious release release a data set, set a date, get people together, run a challenge, hear some topics, Q&A and ad hoc, and see what happens. That's the default approach. Is there something you want to do that's better or more novel than that? Does anybody have any ideas? Let's worry about the challenge first and the hackathon. Well the question is does the challenge have to have one single task or could it be multiple ones? It's a plus. There's a workshop and I imagine there will be an associated workshop and a grand challenge tied to the workshop. Because I think they're having a remote workshop. Yeah, I was also thinking like thinking like, given the bias we'll have in the dataset, there is a lot of research on multimedia for cooking, eating, so basically one task could be basically do whatever you have on your dataset and just test it on this dataset. Don't use any training data from this dataset. See how this transfers to new data. And of course, I guess we want to do something like more LSC style interactive queries. I mean, from the backlog of things that we want to do is one thing that we always, for VPS also, was trying to see how precisely you phrase queries or how simple you keep the language. There is always this tension between use simple words that everyone understands versus being precise so that might be something also to study but this is of course needs comparison so either you split it up to groups if we have enough participants that would work but we don't know in advance probably I think we should build a hybrid benchmark for everyone to compare their model when they create a new idea. But for annual competitions, we should change the task to a new one and motivate them to create a new idea or change the method to commit with other teams. So yeah, that's my idea. The usual Grand Challenge format, which I think we should stick to at least for the part that we label as a challenge, is an asynchronous operation. You get your data, you get your task, you get your time, your process to do whatever it is you think you need to do to solve the task, you send in your results, you get your scores back, and there's going to be result presentation of everybody or the top scoring teams. So it's not very alike to LSE and VBS? Yeah, I mean this is something we can do on top of this. That we have a session where something happens live. I think that's what they literally asked us. I mean, that's one thing that makes this format very unique, this interaction. And why is it kind of, I think, interesting that we look at some form of interaction in the age of these conversational systems, because these are conversational systems being from the beginning. So we can do some kind of data mining where they build a system, more like exploration system, and then at the challenge we will have very specific questions for that. For example, regarding group dynamics, so they will have to build a system that can visualize the group dynamics and show some kind of interaction like more and very user experience space and then at the challenge we do we ask some question live and they have to use the system to answer that it's like uh who did i talk to the most today or something like that but these questions are only released at the challenge live. I would just not limit it to something like this because the the barrier of entry for these sort of things is very high so you need a complete stack to be able to do this interactively. Asynchronous. Whereas if you just give out some tasks, people

can put some algorithms together however they want. It only needs to run exactly once on whatever resources they might have, and they can produce those results. This might not cover all the things but but it is certainly for some interesting tasks. It might be entirely sufficient that they can build their thing, it runs on whatever they have. It will take a while to run. We will produce some output, we will look at the output and tell them how well they did. So something that has a low barrier to entry, asynchronous submission to take part in the Grand Challenge, but there is an attractive element to the Grand Challenge which is to a workshop, which is somehow different to the Hackathon. And I guess the Hackathon should have all the things we can not evaluate, whereas there is, either we don't have a ground truth or there cannot be a ground truth because there is some ambiguity there. Whereas the challenges should have a clear mechanism by which you can tell, okay, how much of this you got right. We kind of do this with NTCIR, right? That email I send out periodically and everybody ignores. We kind of do this with NTCIR where we do have this asynchronous challenge. You build your system, you give me the queries, we reach the queries, the queries are more descriptive than an LSE query. It has a title, a and then a narrative that says oh and eating breakfast is relevant only if it includes Werner or a description like that makes it very very clear and people do that in their own time by a certain date they submit the runs we pool all people's runs together and generate the ground truth we don't evaluate everything it's not a complete ground truth it's a pool whole ground truth. So it's never gonna be perfect, but it's gonna be sufficient to differentiate existence. That we can do, not a lot of work. Okay, that's simple, we do that a lot of work. The challenge here is that it's probably a bit more difficult than it is in the real world. That's great. Then we can do some really interesting interaction things in the ATT&CK workshop, where the queries are different, like some kind of, really there's this interaction queries we have. The time I was talking to Ali about the EMPCR query we hadn't yet released. What was the outcome of that conversation? Those kind of things. Much nicer things to do. And that's really interesting, I think, for an interactive challenge. Not just finders. But this is a different... This is also somewhat difficult to evaluate because you need to phrase this very precisely because what was the outcome of this conversation is not something that has a precise answer. We want to show in New York using all this wealth of social media data from different perspectives. So competing teams had totally different solutions.
